selected_quotes: Free article: The effect of duty hour regulations on outcomes of neurological surgery in training hospitals in the US
LA REGLAMENTACIÓN DE LAS HORAS DE TRABAJO EN LOS RESIDENTES DE NEUROCIRUGÍA Y SU FRACASO
Reduced neurosurgical resident hours yield no significant positive effect on patient outcomes.

citation.abstract: The effects of sleep deprivation on performance have been well documented and have led to changes in duty hour regulation. New York State implemented stricter duty hours in 1989 after sleep deprivation among residents was thought to have contributed to a patient's death. The goal of this study was to determine if increased regulation of resident duty hours results in measurable changes in patient outcomes.
citation.title: The effect of duty hour regulations on outcomes of neurological surgery in training hospitals in the United States: duty hour regulations and patient outcomes.

news.title: U of M study finds a reduction in neurosurgical resident hours appears to have no significant positive effect on patient outcomes
news.summary: A reduction in neurosurgeon resident duty hours appears to result in no significant changes in patient outcomes, according to new research from the Department of Neurosurgery at the University of Minnesota.
